explanation:
memset: This is the <string.h> function used directly in the target function. To check for MISRA violations you must inspect the pointer argument (&custom_attr) and the size argument (sizeof(custom_attr)) and confirm the call cannot access beyond the bounds of the referenced object and that the size parameter is expressed in bytes as expected by memset.

strerror: Although not one of the example functions in the MISRA wording, strerror is declared in string.h on many platforms and returns a pointer to a string used with "%s" in OS_DEBUG. Provide its prototype/behavior to confirm it returns a valid NUL-terminated string and that no out-of-bounds access can occur when that pointer is consumed by the debug formatting.

OS_DEBUG: The macro/function used to consume the string returned by strerror (format "%s"). Its implementation matters: if OS_DEBUG copies or stores the string into a fixed-size buffer, that copy could cause an out-of-bounds access even though strerror itself does not. Include OS_DEBUG to determine whether the combination of strerror + OS_DEBUG could violate the MISRA rule.

pthread_attr_t (type/sizeof information): The memset call uses sizeof(custom_attr). To prove the memset size does not exceed the object's bounds you need the concrete definition (or at least its sizeof) of pthread_attr_t on the target platform. Also some types are not safely zeroed by memset; while MISRA Rule here concerns bounds, the type definition will show whether memset(&custom_attr, sizeof(custom_attr)) is appropriate and within bounds.
